headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thank you. Terry, you mentioned in your remarks that the run rate EPS was $0.66. I just wanted to get an idea if that was a good baseline number to use for future periods and the reason I’m asking is that corporate investment income seemed very high
componenttext: Hi, thank you. Terry, you mentioned in your remarks that the run rate EPS was $0.66. I just wanted to get an idea if that was a good baseline number to use for future periods and the reason I’m asking is that corporate investment income seemed very high this quarter. I think it’s on $30 million versus $12.5 million in the second quarter and you didn’t allude to that as an unusual?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the $0.66 that we alluded to in the call is a good run rate for this quarter. One of things that we talked about in the past is, you can’t necessarily have the run rate off of that because of seasonality. Now with the exit of the Health business
componenttext: I think the $0.66 that we alluded to in the call is a good run rate for this quarter. One of things that we talked about in the past is, you can’t necessarily have the run rate off of that because of seasonality. Now with the exit of the Health business, we’ve seen less seasonality. So, on a go forward basis, this probably would be a better base to move off. There are lots of moving parts in terms of EPS, and there’s a lot of things that we’ll be calling out one direction or another, but we felt that the $0.66 was the good solid EPS number for this quarter.

componenttext: The reason that you’ll see it go down a little in the next quarter is, it will have the component of corporate overhead from the Health business. It’s about $7 million be in there. So, all other things being equal, you’d see that change in the Corporate segment.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick one on capital deployment, you mentioned you had deployable capital in the $500 million plus range. Obviously, you did raise the dividend, but how should we think about buyback? Are you likely to deploy most of that over the next yea
componenttext: And then just a quick one on capital deployment, you mentioned you had deployable capital in the $500 million plus range. Obviously, you did raise the dividend, but how should we think about buyback? Are you likely to deploy most of that over the next year or will it be more over the next couple of years or how you think about how you’re going to use up that capital?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean again, just to reiterate, I mean, I think the good news is, is that we’re seeing our businesses perform at a higher level. We’re seeing AUM now back at I think $306 billion. The highest point we reached prior to the financial crisis was $311 bi
componenttext:
I mean again, just to reiterate, I mean, I think the good news is, is that we’re seeing our businesses perform at a higher level. We’re seeing AUM now back at I think $306 billion. The highest point we reached prior to the financial crisis was $311 billion. So, I think that says a lot about the opportunities for growing our operating earnings going forward.
Having said that, again, I think the main reason for caution as I was describing earlier and I guess the way I would think about is, is that I think as we continue to get into each quarter of 2011, I think the likelihood increases around the opportunity to potentially have some budget if you will for M&A as well as some budget for return of capital to shareholder in some fashion and obviously given where the stock is trading today, our share repurchase is a very, very attractive option I said in my comment. So, I’d expect we’ll be able to do both M&A and some level of return of capital during 2011.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: But unlikely that you use up most of this?
componenttext: But unlikely that you use up most of this?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Larry, first just wanted to go back to you mentioned Solvency II as a constraint by 2013, 2014. Now that’s a European Capital Standard, how is that specifically going to affect Principal? That’s my first question. Why don’t I start dow
componenttext: Good morning. Larry, first just wanted to go back to you mentioned Solvency II as a constraint by 2013, 2014. Now that’s a European Capital Standard, how is that specifically going to affect Principal? That’s my first question. Why don’t I start down, I have a few follow-ups?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, we will try to deal with them fairly quickly. I mean the reality is of course I mentioned Solvency II just because they are further along in Europe than they are here in the U.S. and the reality is that not only do the Europeans not have clarity exa
componenttext:
Okay, we will try to deal with them fairly quickly. I mean the reality is of course I mentioned Solvency II just because they are further along in Europe than they are here in the U.S. and the reality is that not only do the Europeans not have clarity exactly on how Solvency II but the U.S. is behind that. There is even sort of less clarity for U.S. companies, but I think Tom that any reasonable person would conclude that having gone through the financial crisis that we’ve gone through, capital standards are likely to increase but not likely to decrease.
And furthermore I’d say we have the unknown here in United States of not knowing exactly what Dodd-Frank is going to do relative to systemically significant institutions and while, again, we may know more about that in six months or nine months but that I think also remains one of the things that we have to think about as we get over the longer term.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next few questions I had, first is, I don’t know if Dan Houston is here. Can you comment on what gives you the confidence in the FSA sales guidance? I understand the October sales are strong but we still got two months left. Are there a few large ca
componenttext: The next few questions I had, first is, I don’t know if Dan Houston is here. Can you comment on what gives you the confidence in the FSA sales guidance? I understand the October sales are strong but we still got two months left. Are there a few large cases in the pipeline, so maybe a little more granularity there and then the next couple are overall, do you expect any meaningful change in your corporate tax rate into 2011 whether its due to the DRD or foreign tax rate changes and then lastly, when you commented on your ESOP mandates being quite strong is this included in your FSA sales and if so is that a much lower margin business? I’ll leave it there. Thanks.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I may be try to comment quickly on it because again I know we’re trying to get others in as well but the ESOP that we discussed in the comments Tom, is just relative to ESOP consulting assignments those haven’t necessarily turned in at this point to F
componenttext:
I may be try to comment quickly on it because again I know we’re trying to get others in as well but the ESOP that we discussed in the comments Tom, is just relative to ESOP consulting assignments those haven’t necessarily turned in at this point to FSA sales or ongoing ability to manage and generate assets but again, what we’re trying to give you is a leading indicator of where that particular part of the business is going which is a very positive one. As you said lesser margins, we’ve commented on that. It’s primarily consulting fees.
In terms of corporate tax rate, DRD is running about the same level as it has run in years past. It’s been around the range of $75 million. I suppose one could speculate that maybe corporations sitting with a $1 trillion of cash on their collective balance sheets might be paying out more dividends, but we haven’t seen sort of clear trends in that. We are seeing on the international side, I think there is going to be some increase in tax rates. It’s a good problem, but we kind of burned through some of the loss carryforwards related to international, and maybe I’ll have Dan comment on FSA sales.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, couple quick comments. Tom, the ESOP assets are counted in our Full Service numbers, the number for the third quarter was $220 million versus the prior quarter of $129 million. So, you can see it’s not a hugely disproportionate percentage of our sa
componenttext:
Yes, couple quick comments. Tom, the ESOP assets are counted in our Full Service numbers, the number for the third quarter was $220 million versus the prior quarter of $129 million. So, you can see it’s not a hugely disproportionate percentage of our sales and again we write very few standalone ESOP. Most of these come along with a significantly 401(k) set of assets as well. Just a couple of quick measures, they’d give us confidence around Q4. One would be around the sheer number of advisors requesting a proposal likely to be on track this year to hit a record high, which tells us that our efforts in building our alliance partnerships are good. We’ve got about a 5% increase on a year-to-date basis of our pipeline. Our close rates have ticked up nicely.
We also had, if you look at the number of plans sold roughly up 21% and we are showing good track record there in the other. In closing comment I have made is the TPA initiative is well underway. We’re seeing very good tracking working with those advisors that prefer a local TPA. We’ve dedicated a lot of time and resources this past year, and we feel out there is good demand in Q4 moving forward. Hopefully that helps.

componenttext: So, 2.5 and then just a follow-up on one of the piece of those comments, you mentioned that you had a natural offset from interest rates rising in another courtiers, is that a reference to kind of foreign bonds you hold in the general account or is that more a comment on how AUM would benefit through the income statement.

componenttext: Well I would say it’s just a more of a general comment. I want to ask Jim sort of comment relative to things he is seeing in the global market around rising rates and again you’ve seen a number of central banks already begin to raise rates, so Jim might want to comment.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, with very low interest rate environment, (inaudible) which we are probably going to see enhanced by the Federal Reserve this week, is going to be led to very sustained low rates here and I think the 2.50 rate that was talked about for the 10-year yie
componenttext: Yes, with very low interest rate environment, (inaudible) which we are probably going to see enhanced by the Federal Reserve this week, is going to be led to very sustained low rates here and I think the 2.50 rate that was talked about for the 10-year yield is really our forecast, but it could lower, it could go a bit higher. Obviously not problematic for the U.S. business, as has been described, but you have seen some rate rises from economies that are growing much faster Brazil, China and Australia and that will continue and that has a beneficial impact on some of our businesses in Principal International. It’s not foreign bonds within the general account. We are very tightly managed and tightly matched in the general account. That’s not what it is, but the impact is more on assets under management and on our general accounts in our international businesses.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Just two questions. First on capital management; Larry, the stock is at book value and feeling like you are near an inflection point for the business, a business that got you more than a two times book value multiple pre-crisis. I’m not sayin
componenttext: Thank you. Just two questions. First on capital management; Larry, the stock is at book value and feeling like you are near an inflection point for the business, a business that got you more than a two times book value multiple pre-crisis. I’m not saying, we’re going back there but I guess what I want to hear how compelling would some type of acquisition have to be that would make it even close to as attractive as what your stock is today and then I have just one quick follow-up?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s a good question Ed and trust me relative to the management team and the Board, we get that. We do understand that. I do think that there are some M&A possibilities. To be honest, they’re not of course nearly as large and sort of headlin
componenttext:
I think that’s a good question Ed and trust me relative to the management team and the Board, we get that. We do understand that. I do think that there are some M&A possibilities. To be honest, they’re not of course nearly as large and sort of headline grabbing as something like an Alco [ph] might be but I will also tell you, I think over the long-term, there may actually be more value creation because I think we have demonstrated very clearly over the time we’ve been a public company that one of our greatest capabilities is to take some sort of competency and attach that to our distribution engine whether that’s here in the U.S. or our global distribution platform and really maximize the value coming out of that.
So as we look forward, for example, we see a lot of opportunity, the need around emerging market asset management is going to be huge and we are extremely well positioned to do that. So we see it and it’s not an either or question Ed. What I’m trying to communicate here is we see the possibility to do some very attractive over the longer term M&A. It may not be quite as accretive in the near term, it will be very attractive in the long-term and that still wouldn’t necessarily keep us from doing some level of share repurchase as we get into the middle part, later part of 2011. So it’s not either or it’s both end and I think you’ll see us take actions as we get into 2011.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The one follow-up is on your discussion around run rate EPS. I think we’ve got a sort of definitional issue perhaps where you talk about $0.66 for this quarter as being run rate number, but I don’t know that - when we think about run rate it’s sort
componenttext: The one follow-up is on your discussion around run rate EPS. I think we’ve got a sort of definitional issue perhaps where you talk about $0.66 for this quarter as being run rate number, but I don’t know that - when we think about run rate it’s sort of what we would think about growing earnings off of and I guess is it fair to say that if we had more normalized DAC amortization, more normalized corporate that maybe that number could grow off of it, it’s more like $0.63 rather than $0.66?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we’re trying to communicate the same thing. Maybe we are not saying it in all exactly the same lingo Ed, but once again there’s a number of kind of offsetting factors that go into there. So there seems to be as you indicated, may be ther
componenttext: Well, I think we’re trying to communicate the same thing. Maybe we are not saying it in all exactly the same lingo Ed, but once again there’s a number of kind of offsetting factors that go into there. So there seems to be as you indicated, may be there’s a lesser amount this quarter, may be there’s a lesser amount of FSA DAC amortization, but there would be equal numbers of offsetting factors that in our view would say we think $0.66 is a fair run rate and you then apply the normal metrics relative to growing AUM and other things that would then get you to what would be the Q4 run rate and going into 2011. So I think we are talking the same thing when we talk about $0.66.

componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. Wanted to explore one area which is, I mean obviously the commentary is more positive around the sales numbers, but the plan count continues to decline about 3% year-over-year, continues to decline sequentially albeit slightly better tha
componenttext: Hi, good morning. Wanted to explore one area which is, I mean obviously the commentary is more positive around the sales numbers, but the plan count continues to decline about 3% year-over-year, continues to decline sequentially albeit slightly better than it did last quarter, and I guess in the past you’ve attributed to plan terminations, fewer new plan startups, I guess the question is when do you think that the plans are going to stabilize generally, but I think more important than that is if you strip out the impact of plan terminations and normalized kind of new starts, what would that plan count look like sequentially or year-over-year, how you want to look at it.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan would want to comment, but in rough terms what we’ve been seeing the last few quarters, again predicting the future is not quite as easy, Mark, but in rough terms what we’ve been seeing in the past is we’ve been seeing about 200 plans per quarte
componenttext: Dan would want to comment, but in rough terms what we’ve been seeing the last few quarters, again predicting the future is not quite as easy, Mark, but in rough terms what we’ve been seeing in the past is we’ve been seeing about 200 plans per quarter, fewer start up plans, about 200 per quarter and we’ve been seeing in rough terms about 100 more plans terminations per quarter. So, that’s kind of that net difference of about 300 plans per quarter over the last kind of four to six quarters. So, I will let Dan be a prognosticator, the one who is going to go away.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick comments. The takeover plans were down approximately 30% from where there were a year ago. Startup plans from year ago were down 50%. If we just look at plan terms, remember that’s different than contract terms. These are people who ha
componenttext:
A couple of quick comments. The takeover plans were down approximately 30% from where there were a year ago. Startup plans from year ago were down 50%. If we just look at plan terms, remember that’s different than contract terms. These are people who have eliminated their plans. They are down 30% from a year ago and contract terms are up about 10%.
When we look at that period of time in the historical ‘04 through ‘07 time frame, what you’d really find out is our contract withdrawals are up about 100 basis points from a normal run rate. Still the biggest efficiency we have is around transfer deposits. It’s up 300 basis points compared to the same period of time. If you look closely and talk to the advisors, what they would tell you is that it seems like we’ve reached kind of at the bottom here, relative to the economic recovery and it’s a slow build out from here. But we feel genuinely optimistic about our ability to retain plans through some of our revised service models that help lower the price to our TPA initiative and through our expanded lines partnerships.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on some of the new fee disclosures that are required. Have you seen any changes in pricing or have yourselves made any material changes in pricing directly as a result of some of the new disclosures. I know that you guys kind of have historically dis
componenttext: Just on some of the new fee disclosures that are required. Have you seen any changes in pricing or have yourselves made any material changes in pricing directly as a result of some of the new disclosures. I know that you guys kind of have historically disclosed maybe a little bit more than some others have, but what has been the impact on pricing generally and how should we think about that in terms of FSA margins?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think we moved the needle at all today to today’s pricing. Remember we’ve got July of 2011 date, which employers will have to disclose this and there is a participant disclosure that takes place 01/01/2012. There is a still a lot of back and
componenttext: I don’t think we moved the needle at all today to today’s pricing. Remember we’ve got July of 2011 date, which employers will have to disclose this and there is a participant disclosure that takes place 01/01/2012. There is a still a lot of back and forth in form of labor finding the most efficient way to illustrate that, both as a basis point and a dollar amount, but to your point, Mark, we have been quite aggressive in disclosure in the past. We’ve worked with a large client, so there is no surprise out there. This probably has way more to do with geography and how to illustrate and it doesn’t change in the overall pricing.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. All right. Thank you.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark.
componenttext: Thanks, Mark.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Berg with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Berg with Barclays Capital.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much and good morning. What I’m trying to do is to reconcile the continued cautious commentary by the leading group insurers, many of which are operating in the same market as you with your optimism. In another words, if the unemployment rat
componenttext: Thanks very much and good morning. What I’m trying to do is to reconcile the continued cautious commentary by the leading group insurers, many of which are operating in the same market as you with your optimism. In another words, if the unemployment rate remains as high as it is and if business confidence remains by your own acknowledgement quite subdued, especially in the middle market and as well if the group insurers, the big sellers of group life and group disability against whom you compete in the same middle of the market are saying that business remains very slow reflecting an overall soft economy. My first question, I have only two, is why do you think the 401(k) business is at an inflection point?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Larry. I mean again the only thing I know about is the actual history and again, we’ve seen now for the second quarter in a row we’ve seen increases in the recurring deposits coming out of Full Service Accumulation kind of quarter-over-q
componenttext: Eric, this is Larry. I mean again the only thing I know about is the actual history and again, we’ve seen now for the second quarter in a row we’ve seen increases in the recurring deposits coming out of Full Service Accumulation kind of quarter-over-quarter. So that’s I think the most powerful lead indicator that I can give you that as Dan said just a minute ago, we sort of reached the bottom and we’ve now started to actually build back on positive basis. That’s not necessarily because employment is growing, but at least employment shrinkage has stopped. We’re starting to see deferrals come up a little bit, so we’re starting to see matches come back a little bit. So those things is what’s driving the increase in recurring deposits, we’ve now seen that two quarters in a row and we’d expect that to continue based on everything we see every day.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second and final question relates to your forecast of what I believe is based on the risk we take here more than a doubling of December quarter sales over year ago December quarter sales at least I think that’s what your forecast for the middle of th
componenttext:
My second and final question relates to your forecast of what I believe is based on the risk we take here more than a doubling of December quarter sales over year ago December quarter sales at least I think that’s what your forecast for the middle of the range for growth would imply. My question is do you really truly think that it’s fair to sort of reach that conclusion so early on based on things like request for bids from brokers and the fact that you have some more consulting assignments, I mean I would think a much firmer handle could be had by answering the question how many deals do we have in place in which we are extremely close? Not how many times is the phone ringing or how many consulting assignments do we have?
I just want to know whether why you think that these variables that you cited are enough to make what would appear to be a very optimistic sales forecast for the remaining two months of the year or is there more that you’re not telling us at this point. Thank you. That will be all.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we’re all in the same page, right. We’re all in the same page and what we’re talking about are what we believe to be our best estimates if you will of commitments that is plans that do have every intention to transfer to us over the remainin
componenttext:
I think we’re all in the same page, right. We’re all in the same page and what we’re talking about are what we believe to be our best estimates if you will of commitments that is plans that do have every intention to transfer to us over the remaining, if you will, now two months of the year. So, it is in large measure based on commitments.
Having said that, I’ve been around this business long enough that I have seen plans that told us they were going to transfer on 12/15 come in on 1/15/2011. Now that’s not going to make any difference over the longer term trend lines if you will for the business, but there is always just a level of cautiousness and conservatism relative to is everything that we are told is going to show up in December might some of that carryover into the first quarter.
All that’s possible but if we apply all of our kind of normal experience, we look at all of the measures that we get from our sales offices, we do expect to have that kind fourth quarter in the range that you indicate but there is always one or two plans that can fall one way or the other that might influence it, but we feel very good about where we’re going for the reasons Dan mentioned, close rates are up, investment performance is strong, advisors are coming back. So we think we are going into a period when we’re going to have wind at our back.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very helpful, thank you.
componenttext: Very helpful, thank you.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You bet.
componenttext: You bet.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Colin Devine with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Colin Devine with Citi.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Larry, a couple of questions. First, you talked about Solvency III and Principal’s base reserving but it would seem to that certainly relative to the Life peer group, the protection businesses are a much smaller part of your story. All of
componenttext:
Good morning. Larry, a couple of questions. First, you talked about Solvency III and Principal’s base reserving but it would seem to that certainly relative to the Life peer group, the protection businesses are a much smaller part of your story. All of the focuses, whether it’s Solvency, whether it’s IFRS, they are really driven on the liability side, which again is where you haven’t taken the risk, unlike perhaps the variable annuity writers. I’m not sure why you’re as cautious about that, maybe you could help us with that?
Secondly, I think the big question here on capital management, Larry, as I remember in analyst meeting a couple of years ago, where you were up there and talking about an ROE projection, getting up to 16%, 17%, 18%, here we’re stuck in under 10% and if I take your number, okay, of what the true if like excess is of 5 to 7.50, and we take that out maybe we can stretch the ROE for the company this quarter to 11%, but what doesn’t seem to be addressed to me is why are you running 400 to 500 to 600 points than below what you said before was your goal when the projection business is even going to be smaller now?
And then finally, Terry, could you just clarify what the DAC adjustments were on the Life line, was that related to secondary guarantee, well, and what did you change?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just quickly on your questions, as we’re kind of closing in on time here, but as it relates to Solvency II, I think I indicated in my response Colin to one of the earlier questions that again, we agree that while we will be impacted less by whatever Sol
componenttext:
Just quickly on your questions, as we’re kind of closing in on time here, but as it relates to Solvency II, I think I indicated in my response Colin to one of the earlier questions that again, we agree that while we will be impacted less by whatever Solvency II and new capital requirements are, this company will be impacted by them to a lesser degree.
But having said that, it is one of the important things that we’re looking at, along with as I said before, the whole question from the Financial Stability Oversight Council as to what is going to be a systemically significant institution. I think that is one that probably is going to happen sooner and may well in fact involve us as compared to some of the other life peers, so that’s something we need to think about.
In terms of ROE, again the issues, if you look at the fundamental businesses that we’re running, I will still argue much as I did three, four years ago that we have the ability to build ROE to a higher level than do many of our Life peers. Now at the current time, again we are in a period where there doesn’t seem to be that much value from the standpoint of investors in terms of wanting to see that ROE improvement. I think that will change over time and I think we will be more confident in rationalizing our capital base to grow our ROE over time, but I am every bit as confident of our ability over the long-term to hit a 15% ROE today as I was back in 2004 and 2005.
And in fact we do projections every year, we do very detailed projections and as you know, we remain committed to that one rule of thumb that indicates we plan to grow ROE 50 basis points a year because as we began to shift towards international and asset management and asset accumulation, our ROE’s potential is probably higher today than it was in 2005. So again it’s just a matter of time and it’s a rationalization of capital and I’ll let Terry cover the DAC amortization.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the DAC amortization in the Life Line is on a run rate basis is probably in the $15 million to $20 million range. It was lower than that this quarter because of this noise that we had as a result of reinsurance not getting reflected in the current pe
componenttext: Yes, the DAC amortization in the Life Line is on a run rate basis is probably in the $15 million to $20 million range. It was lower than that this quarter because of this noise that we had as a result of reinsurance not getting reflected in the current period comparable to the last period, although we didn’t call it out as such because are more challenging, more than offset that our expected losses were in line with what we expected, but in terms of the DAC amortization was increased because of on each year annually we review our models and our assumptions in this quarter is when we did that and we had an impact of probably around on an after-tax basis of around $6 million and so that had the impact this quarter, that’s why we called it out.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, I was asking what assumptions did you change, we’ve heard about Ameriprise doubling their VA DAC from 20 to 40 years, you know their fixed annuity DAC taking it to 30, what assumptions did you change?
componenttext: Terry, I was asking what assumptions did you change, we’ve heard about Ameriprise doubling their VA DAC from 20 to 40 years, you know their fixed annuity DAC taking it to 30, what assumptions did you change?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: They were wide variety of assumptions we took into consideration lapses in terms of earnings, in terms of capitalizations that we’ve had in the past as well.
componenttext: They were wide variety of assumptions we took into consideration lapses in terms of earnings, in terms of capitalizations that we’ve had in the past as well.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, we look at all the experience assumptions Colin, we did not make any particular changes in those same comparable things that Ameriprise talked about ours is if you will just a tweeting of the various experience assumptions that go into a DAC calculati
componenttext: So, we look at all the experience assumptions Colin, we did not make any particular changes in those same comparable things that Ameriprise talked about ours is if you will just a tweeting of the various experience assumptions that go into a DAC calculation. We do once a year. It’s a typical exercise.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Larry with all due respect and maybe you can do this on Investor Day, but you really did not answer the question as to why the ROE is sitting at under 10 today. It’s back where it was really in 2003. What’s under achieving because just simply de
componenttext: Okay, Larry with all due respect and maybe you can do this on Investor Day, but you really did not answer the question as to why the ROE is sitting at under 10 today. It’s back where it was really in 2003. What’s under achieving because just simply deploying your excess capital gets it to 11 and by the way your goal back in ‘03 and ‘04 is what you laid out, was you were marching to 17 to 18 ROE, but I just don’t understand what’s the shortfall because of and until you can identify that I don’t know how you can expect us to have comfort that Principal can get back to 15 because you haven’t addressed why it’s below that now.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I said Colin, our businesses can produce ROEs at the same level they have historically and we need to work our way through the financial crisis, we need to work our way through to a period where I think both managements and Boards feel more comfo
componenttext: Sure. As I said Colin, our businesses can produce ROEs at the same level they have historically and we need to work our way through the financial crisis, we need to work our way through to a period where I think both managements and Boards feel more comfortable in rationalizing a denominator. It’s a denominator issue as compared to, if you will, an inherent run rate of the businesses but we’ll look forward to talking more about at Investor Day. Thanks.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Giovanni with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Giovanni with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most have been answered, just one question in terms of the favorable outlook of October if you can comment in terms of the sales, has it been one or two large cases that have driven that or has it been broad strength in the small and mid-case channels.
componenttext: Most have been answered, just one question in terms of the favorable outlook of October if you can comment in terms of the sales, has it been one or two large cases that have driven that or has it been broad strength in the small and mid-case channels.

componenttext: It really is, Chris a combination of both. Couple of nicer size cases, but frankly an increase in just the sheer number of small- to medium-sized business is driven by our TPA solutions that drove our numbers up for October.

componenttext: And then lastly, I think last quarter, you commented that roughly 20% or so of the companies that pulled their match programs and reinstated. Can you provide us with an update this quarter?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Principal Financial Group's third quarter earnings conference call.As always, our earnings release, financial supplement, and additional investment portfolio detail are available on our website, at www.princip
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to the Principal Financial Group's third quarter earnings conference call.
As always, our earnings release, financial supplement, and additional investment portfolio detail are available on our website, at www.principal.com/investor. Following the reading of the Safe Harbor provisions, CEO Larry Zimpleman, and CFO Terry Lillis, will deliver some prepared remarks. Then we'll open up the call for questions. Others available for the Q&A are Dan Houston, US Asset Accumulation and US Insurance Solutions; Jim McCaughan, Principal Global Investors; Norman Sorensen, Principal International; and Julia Lawler, Chief Investment Officer.
Some of the comments made during the conference call may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. The Company does not revise or update them to reflect new information, subsequent events, or changes in strategy. Risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied, are discussed in the Company's most recent annual report, on Form 10-K, and quarterly report on Form 10-Q, filed by the Company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Before I turn the call over to Larry, I'd like to remind everyone that the Principal Financial Group will host its 2010 Investor Day at afternoon of December 9 and the St. Regis Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. We'll give a detailed look at our lines of business, our strategy the U.S. and in international markets where we operate and discuss our vision for the future. We hope everyone can attend or listen via the webcast. Additionally, we will announce 2011 EPS guidance prior to the investor day, to our press release and conference call. You will receive details about the call shortly. Larry?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will focus my comments on three areas this morning. First, results for the third quarter in the first 9 months of 2010. Second, thoughts on capital management and third, progress on the implementation o
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and welcome to everyone on the call. I will focus my comments on three areas this morning. First, results for the third quarter in the first 9 months of 2010. Second, thoughts on capital management and third, progress on the implementation of our strategy during these challenging times. Terry will then cover financial results in more detail following my comments. Overall, we are pleased with the performance of our businesses in third quarter and see increasing signs of growth across the businesses. We saw a sequential improvement in operating earnings, assets under management, book value per share and net income. Operating earnings for the third quarter were $219 million, up 15% from last quarter and up 15% from the year-ago quarter on a normalized basis. Year-to-date earnings increased 19% over last year primarily due to higher assets under management and our ongoing expense discipline.
During the quarter, we saw assets under management grow by over 7% and had $2.3 billion of positive net cash flow from our growth engines. To remind you, we defined the accumulation businesses within U.S. Asset Accumulation Principal Global Investors and Principal International as our higher growth engines. As we look deeper at the business segments, U.S. Asset Accumulation's financial results were solid and the sales picture continues to improve. We view full-service accumulation year-to-date sales of $3.5 billion as positive in an environment that remains challenging. As a reminder, we said full-service accumulation sales will be higher in the second half of this year and we remain confident that we will finish 2010 with full-year sales, 15% to 20% above 2009 full-year results of $5 billion. Total Retirement Suite continues to set us apart from competitors contributing 60% of total full service accumulation sales for 2010. Principal Funds continues to see very strong growth, as a result of having some new and innovative products that appeal to investors. Principal Funds generated a record $790 million of net cash flow for the quarter. An example of these innovative products is our global diversified income fund. Still in its infancy at less than 2 years old, the fund reached $1 million in assets under management this quarter. Fewer than 3% of all the funds registered at the same time have reached the $1 billion milestone. The market continues to search for yield, putting our high yield and preferred securities strategies in high demand. And showcasing our retirement asset allocation expertise all 11 of our target date fund options have top quartile MorningStar Peer Group Performance for the 1-year period.
Principal Global Investors saw a return to a somewhat more normal quarter. Positive unaffiliated net cash flow of $800 million highlights our success in attracting money to specialize investment options, such as real estate and currency, as well as in high yield and international equities. While the number of institutional clients seeking mandates is still depressed, we are seeing activity build each quarter.
Shifting our focus to international markets, Principal International had an outstanding third quarter, with strong net cash flow and investment performance leading to a record $42 billion in assets under management. Despite a lower economic interest in Brasilprev, Principal International remains a strong growth driver as we continue to deliver our retirement and asset management expertise in key emerging markets. Our reach in these markets is extensive. In Brazil, China and Malaysia alone, we have access to more than 200 million individual customers and more than 5 million business customers through our partnerships with Banco Brazil, the largest bank in Latin America; China Construction Bank, the second-largest commercial back in the world; and CIMB Group, the fifth largest financial services provider in Southeast Asia. Our presence in key international markets, most for more than 10 years, gives us an advantage over competitors to capitalize on the rapidly growing middle class and privatization of pension systems. Moving to the risk businesses, in light of our decision to exit insured medical and administrative services only businesses, we renamed the Life and Health Insurance U.S. Insurance Solutions which now comprises the Individual Life and Specialty Benefits division. With year-to-date operating earnings of $141 million, the segment contributes solid earnings and a return on equity of 11.5%. Importantly, this business provides product depth and breadth for the broader financial security needs of small to medium-sized businesses and individuals, and keeps us connected to thousands of advisors that are active in these businesses. Let me comment quickly on our investment portfolio performance this quarter. Once again, credit losses trended down. The portfolio continues to perform better than our beginning of the year expectations thanks to a strong recovery in both corporate credit and commercial real estate. Our portfolio is built for the long-term and the portfolio construction is the right fit to support our liabilities. Purpose of diversification continues to benefit our financial results during this challenging time, whether it be the strength of our international operations, offsetting a slowdown in the U.S. retirement market during the economic crisis or our mix of fee-based and risk-based products. Today, approximately 65% of our company earnings are tied to fee-based products, which are not directly impacted by a low interest rate environment. Less than 10% of Principal lies general and guaranteed separate accounts our credit interest of the minimum guaranteed levels, which means our earnings are much less impacted than our peers in this low interest rate environment.
Signs in the third quarter indicate that the risk of a double-dip recession is fading. However, we expect the U.S. economic recovery to continue to be choppy. The September U.S. Small Business Optimism Index remains unchanged since June and the job market recovery is still sluggish. Despite this, as I mentioned at the outset of the call, our businesses are seeing increased signs of growth and we believe we are at or near an inflection point. Most notably, recurring deposits in full-service accumulation relative to third quarter 2009 increased for the second straight quarter, which we see as a sign of future growth. We're seeing increased interest in Employee Stock Ownership Plans or ESOPs. And thus far in 2010, we've been selected to assist in more than 70 ESOP consulting opportunities, up from 14 in 2009.
ESOP engagements are a window into what is happening in the small and medium-size business market. Our ESOP expertise provides a unique opportunity to cross-sell other retirement products and further capture the assets as the relationship grows over time. A return to positive long-term fund flows in the mutual fund industry and record net cash flow for Principal Funds. Continued strong net cash flow and record assets under management for Principal International. An increase in global institutional search activity driving positive unaffiliated net cash flow for Principal Global Investors. An increase in Specialty Benefits premiums for the second quarter in a row, after 5 quarters of decline, as well as the stabilization of membership levels and a recovery in Individual Life sales both quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year. Overall, the result continue to demonstrate that Principal has the right mix of products and services that advisors, businesses and individuals are looking for as the U.S. economy continues to rebuild.
Now I want to touch on capital management. First of all, as we announced yesterday, we are pleased that our Board of Directors has approved a 10% common stock dividend increase, which is a sign of our confidence in our businesses as well as our commitment to deliver shareholder value. We will continue to weigh all of the options to deploy capital and made decisions that are in the long-term interests of our shareholders. We see increased merger and acquisition opportunities in the international areas and Global Asset Management, which would fit nicely within our business model. In addition, we view share repurchase as an attractive option. With all options, we will be very disciplined as we look to put excess capital to work and we look forward to providing more details on our capital strategy at our Investor Day on December 9.
My third and final topic is to discuss the ongoing implementation of our strategy. Our focus remains the same. To help growing businesses, individuals and Institutional clients achieve financial security and success, we have continued to work on the implementation of our strategy even during the financial crisis, with important steps like renewing our Brasilprev joint venture for 23 years, entering attractive new emerging markets like Indonesia and Thailand, and adding new U.S. distribution relationships like Bank of America Merrill Lynch. We are excited about the long-term growth opportunities for all our businesses. We have the expertise and the right business mix to work with advisors to help the large underserved and underpenetrated market of small-to-medium-sized businesses meet their business owner and employee benefits needs. In the U.S., helped 78 million Baby Boomers, 80 million Echo Boomers and everyone in between with their savings protection retirement income needs. To continue to export and grow our Retirement and Asset Management expertise in select international markets, where we already have an established footprint and strong local distribution partners. And to grow our proven global multi-boutique Asset Management model. Obviously, the biggest strategic decision for the quarter was to wind down the health business, which demonstrates our discipline to focus on our opportunities for growth while maintaining a diversified business portfolio. The investment needed to achieve scale to stay competitive in the rapidly changing healthcare industry did not make sense for us as we focus on overall value for our shareholders. We do not expect the wind down to have any meaningful impact on our Specialty Benefits business. Over the past few years, we have deliberately built specialty benefits as a standalone business with a dedicated sales team and focused employees and infrastructure. Less than 5% of the specialty benefits premiums are tied to medical. Overall, our hybrid business model of Asset Management and risk-based products is poised for superior growth as we look out over the next 10 to 15 years and beyond. We export our U.S. leadership and expertise in Retirement, asset accumulation and Asset Management to select emerging markets. We are in markets with fast growing middle income populations. We're optimistic about the positive momentum we are seeing in all of our lines of business. All opportunities, both domestically and abroad, will deliver long-term results and shareholder value. Before I turn the call over to Terry, I want to point out some recent recognition that we received across our businesses. CIMB-Principal Islamic Asset Management was recently named Best Asset Management House at the International Takaful Awards in London 2010. While currently a small portion of our Global Asset Management business, there is little doubt that Sharia Compliant Funds have great growth potential. We are pleased to get in the ground floor and win awards as we go. Additionally, The Principal was named InformationWeek 500 for the 13th straight year and made our ninth appearance on the Working Mother 100 Best Companies list. We believe this third-party recognition and demonstrates the true character of the organization and that the Principal remains a company, advisors and customers want to do business with and investors can trust. Terry?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. This morning, I'll focus on operating earnings including continued strong Expense Management, details on the accounting indications of our exit from the health business, net income including continued solid performance of the investment por
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. This morning, I'll focus on operating earnings including continued strong Expense Management, details on the accounting indications of our exit from the health business, net income including continued solid performance of the investment portfolio, and finally an update on our improving capital position and strong balance sheet. Again, we view third quarter as solid and have seen several inflection points for many of our lines of business. As Larry highlighted, we are seeing many positive trends and are excited about our growth opportunities going forward. Starting with total company results, third quarter 2010 operating earnings were $219 million or $0.68 per share, flat compared to third quarter last year. However, there were a number of items influencing comparability between periods. These include opportunistic early redemption of medium-term notes in third quarter 2009, the reduced economic interest in our Brasilprev joint venture and the impact of equity markets, model enhancements and assumption changes on DAC amortization. Excluding these items, total company earnings improved 15% over third quarter 2009 on 10% higher average assets under management, a very solid result reflecting our operational leverage. Let me quickly quantify the larger items influencing third quarter 2010 reported earnings per share of $0.68. DAC amortization true-ups for equity market performance and modeling assumptions benefited full-service accumulation, individual annuities and Principal International by $0.04 and negatively impacted individual life by $0.02. Adjusting for significant impacts to DAC amortization, both positive and negative, is consistent with prior periods. As a result, the run rate of earnings for the quarter is $0.66 per share. Now let me discuss the business unit results. Starting with U.S. Asset Accumulation earnings, normalized for strong fee income from early redemption of medium-term notes and third quarter 2009 and DAC amortization true-ups due to equity markets, current quarter earnings are in line with the increase in average account values compared to a prior-year period. Reflecting a continued expense management, full-service accumulation's third quarter 2010 operating earnings are up 14% on a 9% increase in average account values compared to the prior-year quarter. To enforce Larry's earlier comments, our strong October sales further reinforces our confidence that we expect full-service accumulation sales to be up 15% to 20% over last year. We expect to end the year with a positive net cash flow of $800 million to $1 billion against the projected industry outflows in 2010, according to the independent research firm, Cerulli. In the third quarter, Principal Funds had $2.5 billion in sales, record net cash flow of $790 million and continued success from our extensive retail distribution network. The drop in individual annuity earnings from a year ago primarily reflects a $6 million after-tax increase in DAC amortization expense due to equity markets, compared to third quarter 2009 and reduced interest margins in our fixed deferred annuity business. Earnings from Principal Global Investors improved 43% from a year ago. The improvement reflects a 5% growth in average assets under management, strong expense management and a significant increase in transaction fees, which are trending up more to normal levels. Additionally, unaffiliated net cash flow was a positive $800 million. We are cautiously optimistic about future flows as we're starting to see mandate funds in specialized investment options where we have expertise in, such as real estate, currency, high yield and international equities. We are pleased with the third quarter funding of our China Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor or QDII, which is a fund issued by CCB Principal Asset Management that invest in international securities for Chinese investors. The majority of these assets will be managed by PGI. We are one of a select group that has been authorized by the Chinese government to offer this product and although a small step, this is a great opportunity going forward. 
Moving to Principal International where operating earnings were $33 million, third quarter 2010 benefited from a $3 million of DAC amortization's due to favorable market conditions. Principal International has added $8 billion of assets under management year-to-date. $3 billion of that is positive net cash flow resulting in a record $42 billion of assets under management. Earnings were strong despite the lower economic interest in our joint venture business, Brasilprev, which was offset by solid investment performance. When you adjust for foreign exchange inflation in Latin America and the new ownership percentage in Brasilprev, Principal International operating earnings grew at 20% year-over-year. U.S. Insurance Solutions had operating earnings of $47 million for the third quarter compared to $56 million in the prior-year quarter. Individual Life with operating earnings of $23 million compared to $30 million in the year-ago quarter, accounted for the majority of this difference. Operating earnings were negatively impacted by updates due to DAC model and assumptions. Mortality was in line for the quarter despite GAAP reinsurance accounting that required us to defer recognition partially offset by DAC amortization expense. The current quarterly run rate for life operating earnings remains about $30 million. Individual life sales are up 12% quarter-over-quarter and 26% year-over-year. 
Turning to Specialty Benefits, operating earnings were $25 million for the third quarter 2010, compared to $26 million to the prior-year quarter, largely due to the decline in members from a year ago. However, we are pleased that membership is stabilizing and premiums grew again for the second straight quarter after 5 quarters of premium declines. Overall, sales were very strong in the quarter, up 16% over the year-ago quarter because of strong individual disability sales and an increase focus and our core markets for our group lines of business.
Next I'd like to review the accounting treatment impact from the health exit. Earnings from health, which are premiums, fees and claims paid are now excluded from operating earnings and show up in the corporate segment below the line as an other after-tax adjustment. The corporate overhead that was allocated to health, approximately $8 billion after-tax per quarter, is now being included in the corporate segments operating earnings. These changes are retroactive and we will reduced full year 2010 operating earnings per share results $0.18 to $0.20. Therefore, the short-term quarterly run rate for the corporate operating segment will be a negative $25 million to $30 million. As we have demonstrated in the past, we will diligently manage expenses against revenue to offset these additional overhead. And overtime, we expect the corporate operating earnings run rate to return to current quarterly run rate of a negative $20 million to $25 million. Corporate operating earnings for the third quarter 2010 was a negative $24 million. This includes the allocation of overhead expenses from the health exit which was offset by higher interest on excess capital. Additionally, third quarter 2010 corporate segment net income includes a $49 million of one-time after-tax expenses related to plans severance and goodwill write-down as a result of our exit from the health business. The net capital we expect to free up as a result of this transaction is between $100 million and $120 million and will become available as the liabilities roll off our balance sheet. In addition, we anticipate receiving compensation from United Healthcare as the membership transitions, which will be reflected in the other after-tax adjustments in the corporate segment. We will earn  a portion of this starting in fourth quarter 2010 and the rest of this will spread throughout the transition period. Moving to total company net income, we view our $142 million result in the third quarter as solid once you reconcile the accounting treatment for the health business exit. After-tax net realized capital losses continue to trend lower at $31 million in third quarter, compared to $53 million in the year-ago quarter as we continue to see a pattern of improvement in credit-related losses over the past several quarters. We also continue to see sequential improvement in CMBS and commercial mortgage whole loans. Commercial mortgages at $7 million after-tax had its lowest quarter of losses since year-end 2008. Corporate credit losses also remain very low. Our investment portfolio performance continues to reflect the benefit of broad asset diversification and strong asset liability management. Quickly looking at other financial metrics, book value per share excluding AOCI, ended the quarter at a record $27.71 up 5% from a year-ago quarter. We finished the quarter at a $1.5 billion net unrealized capital gain position, up $1.2 billion from last quarter. This is the primary reason that book value per share, including AOCI, was $29.90, also on all-time record. Additionally, our debt-to-capital ratio is 15%. The increase in these financial metrics reflect the ongoing improvement in credit markets as the U.S. economy rebuilds. As Larry indicated, our hybrid business model business is less capital intensive and will help us weather the current low interest rate environment. Of our nearly $60 billion of principal life's general and guaranteed separate accounts, roughly 1/3 includes a minimum interest rate guarantee. And less than 10% is currently at those minimums. Of the remaining portion not yet at minimums, we have average of 75 basis points of cushion above the guaranteed minimum rate. Given our ability to reduce crediting rates, coupled with active interest rate risk management, we estimate a very modest earnings impact due to a low interest rate environment. Interest rates in the international markets we're in are currently increasing, providing a natural hedge to our U.S. business. If the current interest rate environment persists for the foreseeable future, we would expect 2011 earnings to be reduced by 1% to 2%.
Moving to capital adequacy, as of quarter end, we estimate our risk-based capital ratio to be around 450%. Relative to a 350% RBC ratio, we have approximately $2.2 billion of total excess capital, split evenly between the life company and the holding company. Even with our commitment to hold the higher component of excess capital as cushion, currently around $1 billion , we clearly have substantial financial flexibility. As you know, 3 of the 4 rating agencies have the life insurance industry on stable outlook. This, along with improving market fundamentals and our businesses' ongoing ability to generate free cash flow, gives us the ability to increase shareholder value over time through strategic capital redeployment. Once again, we are pleased with our solid results. More importantly we are excited about the developing positive trends in our businesses. This concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, please open the call to questions.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. First, can you give us some help on what I think would be a normal using your terms on normalized run rate for DAC amortization especially in FSA? I've looked back on my notes and I've been expecting it to run at a normalized level of mayb
componenttext: Two quick ones. First, can you give us some help on what I think would be a normal using your terms on normalized run rate for DAC amortization especially in FSA? I've looked back on my notes and I've been expecting it to run at a normalized level of maybe $20 million to $25 million quarterly, but it seems you're normalizing this quarter's results to something that's more in the midteens, I just want to make sure I've got that right.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Larry, I'll have Terry comment on that. I would say I just, for the benefit of kind of recognizing from quarter-to-quarter, there are going to be some variances around DAC amortization as we do true-ups unlocking. But one point I would make before
componenttext: This is Larry, I'll have Terry comment on that. I would say I just, for the benefit of kind of recognizing from quarter-to-quarter, there are going to be some variances around DAC amortization as we do true-ups unlocking. But one point I would make before I turn it over to Terry is that I would tell you that if you actually looked year-to-date for FSA, you will see that the account value is up about 16%, but the DAC organization for year-to-date are up about 4% over the comparable quarters of '09. So again these are the kinds of things that from quarter-to-quarter, we'll go back and forth but when you string the quarters together, I think you get a better picture of how the DAC amortization is going. So I'm kind of encourage to look at that on a year-to-date but I'll have Terry give you the expected quarterly rates.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly, Larry. As you mentioned, John, the run rate we took this with FSA is in that $20 million to $25 million range. This quarter, we had $7 million of actual DAC amortization. The equity market also reduced that because of being up almost 11% this qua
componenttext: Exactly, Larry. As you mentioned, John, the run rate we took this with FSA is in that $20 million to $25 million range. This quarter, we had $7 million of actual DAC amortization. The equity market also reduced that because of being up almost 11% this quarter. So there's about $7 million there. gets into the midteens range as you mentioned before but as Larry mentioned, every quarter has a moving parts and what we have typically done is called out the equity component of that because they do fluctuate quite a bit. And you know, abnormal variance, we'll call those out as well but we just didn't see anything abnormal this quarter. So that's why we only called out equity market component.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question on capital management. And Larry, I guess I'd be remised if I didn't try to get a little bit more from you other than stay tuned for investor day. So maybe if I asked this question this way, can we expect you to manage back down to 200%
componenttext: My second question on capital management. And Larry, I guess I'd be remised if I didn't try to get a little bit more from you other than stay tuned for investor day. So maybe if I asked this question this way, can we expect you to manage back down to 200% or 350% risk-based capital ratio? I mean, in other words, should we really be viewing excess capital as the full $2.2 billion that you guys highlight relative to a 350 or is the deployable amount, let's say in the relatively near term next 1 to 2 years, is the deployable amount really something lower than that?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, John. What I'd say to be really candid with you and others that are listening is nobody knows. Nobody knows whether over time, it's 350 is going to become the standard or is the new standard going to be something closer to 400. I he
componenttext: It's a great question, John. What I'd say to be really candid with you and others that are listening is nobody knows. Nobody knows whether over time, it's 350 is going to become the standard or is the new standard going to be something closer to 400. I hear you and others speculate on that over time and I think the reality is this none of us know the answer to that, which is partly why I think we'll continue to be a little bit cautious. Having said that, we're obviously at the strongest point in our history. Another point I guess I would make is that I think that the insurance industry, just like the banking industry undergoing Basel III, we're going to see new prudential standards. We're going to see Solvency II, we're going to see Principal Base reserves coming to the insurance industry sometime in 2013. I think the good news for us is that with a lesser percentage of our businesses tied to insurance, that will have a less dramatic impact but having said that, there is still some uncertainty. But realistically, I would say that deployable capital today is probably somewhere in that maybe $500 million to $750 million range. I think that the action of the Board took yesterday in terms of 110% increase in dividend should tell you a lot about both of the board things that our businesses are operating as well as how the board kind of sees our excess capital position.

I think it's around $30 million versus $12.5 million the second quarter and you didn't allude to that as an unusual?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Terry. Technically, the 66 that we alluded to in the call is a good run rate for this quarter. One of the things that we've talked about in the past is you can't necessarily have the run rate of that because of seasonality. Now with the exit of th
componenttext: This is Terry. Technically, the 66 that we alluded to in the call is a good run rate for this quarter. One of the things that we've talked about in the past is you can't necessarily have the run rate of that because of seasonality. Now with the exit of the health business, we've seen less seasonality so on a go-forward basis hopefully would be a better base to move off. There's a lot of moving parts in terms of EPS and there's a lot of things that we would call out one direction or another but we thought that 66 was a good solid EPS number for this quarter.

componenttext: This is Larry again, Jimmy. Again, just to reiterate, the good news is that we are seeing businesses perform at a higher level. We're seeing AUM now back at I think $306 billion, the highest point we reached prior to the financial crisis was $311 billion. So I think that says a lot about the opportunities for growing our operating earnings going forward. Having said that, again, I think the remained reason for caution is I was describing earlier. I guess the way I would think about that is I think that as we continue to get into is quarter of 2011, I think the likelihood increase as on the opportunity to but as we have some budget, if you will, for M&A as well as some budget for return of capital to shareholder in some fashion. And obviously, given where the stock is trading today, a share repurchase is very, very attractive option. As I said, in my comments. So I'd expect we'll be able to do both M&A and some level of return of capital during 2011.

componenttext: Larry, first I just wanted to go back, you mentioned Solvency II as a constraint by 2013, 2014, now that's a European capital standard. How is that specifically going to affect Principal? That's my first question. Why don't I start here and I have a follow-up.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll try to deal with it fairly quickly. I mean, the reality is of course, I mentioned Solvency II just because they're further along in Europe and they are here in the U.S. and the reality is that not only to the Europeans not have clarity on how Solven
componenttext: We'll try to deal with it fairly quickly. I mean, the reality is of course, I mentioned Solvency II just because they're further along in Europe and they are here in the U.S. and the reality is that not only to the Europeans not have clarity on how Solvency II but in the U.S. is behind that there's even sort of less clarity for U.S. companies. But I think, Tom, that any reasonable person would conclude that having gone through the financial crisis that we've gone through, capital standards are likely to increase, they're not likely to decrease. And furthermore I'd say, we have the unknown here in the United States of not knowing exactly what Dodd-Frank is going to do relative to systemically significant institutions. And while again, we may know more about that in 6 months or 9 months, but that I think also remains one of the things that we have to think about as we get over the longer term.

componenttext: Okay, understood. The next few questions I had, first is, I don't know if Dan Houston is here, can you comment on what gives you the confidence on the FSA sales guidance. I understand the October sales are strong but we still got 2 months left. Are there a few large cases in the pipeline, so maybe a little more granularity there. And then the next couple are, overall do you expect meaningful change in your corporate tax rate into 2011 whether it's due to the DRD or foreign tax rate changes? And then lastly, when you commented on your ESOP mandates being quite strong, is this included in your FSA sales and if so, is that a much lower margin business?

componenttext: Maybe try to comment quickly on these because again I know are trying to get others in as well but the ESOP that we discussed in the comments on which is relative to ESOP consulting assignments. Those haven't necessarily turn in at this point to FSA sales or ongoing ability to manage generate assets but again what we're trying to give you is a leading indicator of where that particular part of the business is going, which is a very positive one. They do have, as you said, lesser margins we've commented on that as primarily consulting fees. In terms of corporate tax rate, DRD is running about the same level as it has run in years past. Its been around the range of $75 million. I suppose one could speculate that maybe corparations sitting with a trillion dollar of cash on their collective balance sheet might be paying out more dividend but we haven't seen sort of clear trends in that. We are seeing on the international side anything there is going to be some increase in tax rate. We've sort of burn through, it's a good problem but we got it burned through some of the loss carry-forwards relative to international. I think I'll have Dan comment on the FSA sales.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of quick comments, Tom. The ESOP assets are accounted in our full-service numbers. The number for the third quarter was $220 million versus the prior quarter of $129 million. So you can see it's not a huge disproportionate percentage of our sales.
componenttext: Couple of quick comments, Tom. The ESOP assets are accounted in our full-service numbers. The number for the third quarter was $220 million versus the prior quarter of $129 million. So you can see it's not a huge disproportionate percentage of our sales. And again, we write very few stand-alone ESOP. Most of these come along to significant 401(k) set of assets as well. Just a couple of quick measures that gives us confidence around Q4. We would be around the sheer number of advisers requesting proposal likely to be on track this year take a record high, which tells us that our efforts in building our alliance partnerships are good. We've got about 5% increase in the year-to-date basis of our pipeline. Our close rates have taken up nicely here we also had if you look at the number of plans sold, roughly up 21% and we are showing a good track record there and other closing comments I would make is that TPA initiative is well underway. We're seeing very good traction working with those, the advisors that prefer local TPA. We've dedicated a lot of time and resources this past year and we feel like there's good demand in Q4 moving forward. Hopefully that helps.

componenttext: I mean, very low interest rate environment. thing Which you're probably going to see announced by the Federal Reserve this week. It's going to lead to a very sustained low rates. I think the 250 rate that we talked for this annual yield is really our forecast but it could go lower, it could go a bit higher and obviously that's problematic for the U.S. business. But you've seen them, you'd see some rate rises from economies that are growing much faster, Brazil, China and Australia and that will continue and it will and that has the beneficial impact on some of our businesses in Principal International. It's not foreign bonds within the general account. We are very tightly managed and tightly matched in the general account. That's not what it is. But the impact more in assets under management and on our general account in our international businesses.
